title: Why did Jesus warn his disciples not to tell anyone about him, after Peter's great confession? - Quora
tags: Jesus in the Old and New Testament

response.answer_text: It is what is called the “Messianic Secret” that is expressed most in the Gospel of Mark. What goes around comes around; according to the genealogies, Jesus would have had a target on him from the time he was born because he was a descendant of Zadok the High Priest of David’s time and David himself. (This through his ancestor King Jotham.) The prophecies of the Dead Sea Scrolls say that the great king that would come would be both priest and king in the line of David. Long after Jesus was resurrected, his relatives (nephews) were persecuted, called to Rome and crucified, including brothers James and Simon, and great nephews Zacharia and I think the other was Yahuda, according to historians. So Jesus himself told Peter, “My time has not yet come.” And part of that time was his death, which he knew would happen just because of his ancestry and the fact that he was out in the open. He did not want to be taken before he got the message out. And remember, Satan entered Peter right afterward, who would be quite pleased if the disciples shot off their mouths in public - and of course Judas shot his off to the authorities. (Though when Josephus talks about Jesus’ capture, he didn’t mention Judas, only that “the Jewish” leaders paid Pilate, this according to the Slavonic Version.
